text: This is interesting btw because Our Machinery is building a much more generic node based editor than existing popular game engines (Unity, Unreal, Godot, Crytech, etc.) that is also more unified.  Traditionally these node based tools use the same UI/UX (except with Unity, where many tools have completely different UIs :)), but are completely different run-time systems that can only interact it specific, predefined ways.  They also tend to be higher level systems that don't necessary give access to engine internals

elements.text: This is interesting btw because Our Machinery is building a much more generic node based editor than existing popular game engines (Unity, Unreal, Godot, Crytech, etc.) that is also more unified.  Traditionally these node based tools use the same UI/UX (except with Unity, where many tools have completely different UIs :)), but are completely different run-time systems that can only interact it specific, predefined ways.  They also tend to be higher level systems that don't necessary give access to engine internals

text: One cool thing is this explicitly allows someone to create assets using the GPU (not necessarily at runtime) and all game engine features, this don't really exist in other engines afaik, although game engines are way behind tools like Houdini or Notch when it comes to this
